answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
Vickie, that's a great question.  While we don't currently have any measures in place for leadership development, I have a few ideas.
1) Turnover ratio
2) Turnover of management staff
3) Average age of staff
4) Average age of management level staff
5) Employee satisfaction with leadership development opportunities (obtained via employee survey)
Just a couple ideas, I'll be interested to see what others throw out there.
Tom

answers.author: Frank Benest
answers.text:
Vickie,
In my ICMA IQ Report "Creating a Multi-Dimensional Talent Strategy," I suggest a number of metrics for an effective talent development program.  Some of these metrics may apply for your leadership development program.  They include:
Number of qualified applicants for certain pivotal
positions
• Percentage of top applicants hired for pivotal
positions
• Length of time to recruit and hire
• Percentage of A players retained
• Percentage of successful internal promotions to fill
key leadership positions
• Number of hours per year of training or professional
development activities for each employee
• Percentage of operating budget allocated to learning,
training, and professional development
• Percentage of professionals and managers who
exhibit key competencies
• Levels of employee engagement
• Percentage of high-potential employees in the key
talent pool ready to advance now or within 3 years
• Levels of success in addressing certain
external challenges.
If you'd like to further discuss, please contact me at frank@frankbenest.com or (650) 444-6261.  
Frank
